Product and quotient rules
Product and quotient rules
The product rule
Some functions are written as a product of two functions, such as
h(x) =
              (x^2+1)(5x-3)
. Multiplying the derivatives of each factor does not give the
              correct derivative. The product rule gives a direct way to find the derivative without
              first expanding the expression.
In this lesson, we will practice using the product rule with polynomial functions,
              but this technique also works for other types of functions. This rule will allow us to
              find derivatives more efficiently and will prepare us for more complex problems later.
Product rule
If
f
and
g
are differentiable functions, then the derivative of the
              product is
\dfrac{d}{dx}[f(x) \cdot g(x)] = f'(x) \cdot g(x) + f(x) \cdot g'(x)
Note that
f'(x) \cdot g(x) \ + \
              f(x) \cdot g'(x)
can be written as
f'g + fg'
.
In this lesson, we will use the product rule to compute derivatives
            of products
              of two functions.

Lesson Summary
The product rule is used to compute the derivative of the product of two
                differentiable functions.
If
f(x)
and
g(x)
are differentiable functions, the derivative is
                given by
\dfrac{d}{dx} [f(x) \cdot g(x)] = f'(x) \cdot g(x) + f(x) \cdot g'(x).
​
The product rule is often the most efficient strategy to take the derivative of
                a product that involves long polynomials or non-polynomial functions.
The quotient rule
Some functions are formed by dividing one function by another, such as
q(x) =
              \frac{x^2 }{2x+1}
. The quotient rule is used to find the derivative of these
              functions. This lesson will focus on applying the quotient rule to polynomial
              functions, preparing us for handling more complex problems later.
Quotient rule
If
f(x)
and
g(x)
are
            differentiable functions and
g(x) \neq 0
, then
\dfrac{d}{dx}\left(\dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}\right)
            = \dfrac{f'(x)g(x) - f(x)g'(x)}{[g(x)]^2}
Note that
\dfrac{f'(x)g(x) - f(x)g'(x)}{[g(x)]^2}
can be written as
\dfrac{f'g-fg'}{g^2}
.
While the numerator of the quotient rule looks similar to the product rule, the
              quotient rule has a
-
between the two terms in the numerator, not a
+.

h^\prime(x) = 2x

Lesson Summary
The quotient rule is used to compute the derivative of the quotient of two
                differentiable functions.
If
f(x)
and
g(x)
are differentiable functions with
g(x) \neq 0
,
                the derivative is given by
\dfrac{d}{dx}\left(\dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}\right) =
                \dfrac{f'(x)g(x) - f(x)g'(x)}{[g(x)]^2}
.
Applying the product and quotient rules with tables
When two functions are multiplied or divided, the derivative is not simply the
              product or quotient of the individual derivatives. Instead, the product and quotient
              rules must be used. In earlier lessons, these rules were applied to functions written
              algebraically.
In this lesson, the focus will be on applying the rules when the functions are
              presented in tabular or numeric form. A table provides the values of each function and
              the corresponding derivatives at specific points, which can be used directly without
              first working through the formulas.
Ex: For the product rule, if
h(x) = f(x) \cdot g(x)
, then
h'(a) =
                f'(a)g(a) + f(a)g'(a)
when
x=a
.
The process involves identifying the needed values from the table or the problem
              statement and substituting those values into the correct formula.

Applying the product and quotient rules in context
In real life, information about how things change is often given as numbers at
              certain times, not as full equations. If two changing quantities are multiplied or
              divided to make a new quantity, we need the product rule or quotient rule to find how
              fast that new quantity is changing.
Ex: The total yearly income of all citizens in a fictional town called Middletown
              depends on the population and the average income per person. Let
t
be the
              number of years after
2000.
If
P(t)
is the population and
I(t)
is
              the average income per person, then the total income is
T(t) = P(t) \cdot I(t)
.
In this lesson, we will use the values of
P(t)
,
I(t)
, and the rates of
              change to determine how quickly the total income
T(t)
is changing.

            quotient rules

T^\prime(t) = \dfrac{d}{dt} [P(t) \cdot I(t)] = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

P^\prime(t) \cdot I(t)
and
P(t) \cdot I^\prime(t)
, not the difference.
\dfrac{P^\prime(t) \cdot I(t) - P(t) \cdot I^\prime(t)}{[I(t)]^2}
This option is the quotient rule for the derivative of the function
\dfrac{P(t)}{I(t)}
. Apply the product rule instead.
P^\prime(t) \cdot I(t) + P(t) \cdot I^\prime(t)
Applying the product rule to
P(t) \cdot I(t)
results in
\dfrac{d}{dt} [P(t)] \cdot I(t) + P(t) \cdot \dfrac{d}{dt} [I(t)] = P^\prime(t)
                    \cdot I(t) + P(t) \cdot I^\prime(t)
P^\prime(t) \cdot I^\prime(t)
The derivative of a product is not the product of the derivatives.
                    Instead, we use the product rule to find
\dfrac{d}{dt} [P(t) \cdot I(t)].

Product and quotient rules
Find

The product rule applies,
\frac{d}{dx}[f(x) \cdot g(x)] = f'(x) \cdot g(x) +
                  f(x) \cdot g'(x)
, with
f(x) = x^#exponent1# + #constant1#
and
g(x) =
                  x^2 - #constant2#
.
Also,
f'(x) = #exponent1# x^#derived_exponent1#
and
g'(x) = 2x
.
Substituting, we obtain:
\begin{align*}
                  \dfrac{d}{dx} [(x^#exponent1# + #constant1#)(x^2 - #constant2#)] &= f'(x)
                  \cdot g(x) + f(x) \cdot g'(x) && \text{Product rule} \\
                  &= #exponent1# x^#derived_exponent1#(x^2 - #constant2#) + (x^#exponent1# +
                  #constant1#)(2x) && \text{Substitution}
                  \end{align*}

                  \frac{g(x) f^\prime (x) - f(x) g^\prime(x)}{(g(x))^2}
A rectangle’s length
\ell (t)
and width
w(t)
change as a
                function of time. At
t=#t#

the length is
\ell(#t#) = #length#

#length_rate#
meters per hour.
the width is
w(#t#) = #width#
meters and is decreasing at a rate of
#width_rate#
meters per hour.
The area of the
                rectangle is the product:
A(t) = \ell(t) \cdot w(t)
.
Find
A'(#t#)
,
                the rate of change of the area at
t = #t#
hours.
We know that:
\ell (#t#) = #length#
\ell' (#t#) = #length_rate#
w (#t#) = #width#
w' (#t#) = -#width_rate#
Using these values with the product rule gives:
\begin{align*}
                  A(t) &= \ell (t) \cdot w(t)\\
                  A'(t) &= \ell '(t) \cdot w(t) + \ell (t)\cdot w'(t) && \text{Product
                rule} \\
                  A'(#t#) &= \ell '(#t#) \cdot w(#t#) + \ell(#t#)\cdot w'(#t#) &&
                \text{Substitute } t = #t# \\
                  &= #length_rate# \cdot #width# + #length# \cdot (-#width_rate#) &&
                \text{Substitute}\\
                  &= #answer# && \text{Simplify}\\
                  \end{align*}
